However, instead of delivering a bulk flow of parcels to a single picking conveyor, in this system 900, the chute of the upstream conveyor 912 is split into two sections 912a, 912b to divide the bulk flow of parcels into discrete batches, directing the batches to either a first picking area 914a or a second picking area 914b. In this exemplary embodiment, the first robot 20 is configured to engage and transfer parcels from the first picking area 914a to the first place conveyor 916 (in response to instructions (signals) received from the controller 40), and the second robot 22 is configured to engage and transfer parcels from the second picking area 914b to the second place conveyor 918 (in response to instructions (signals) received from the controller 40). In this regard, the first picking area 914a is aligned with the first place conveyor 916, and the second picking area 914b is aligned with the second place conveyor 918. Accordingly, instead of picking parcels from a single area in which all of the parcels within the bulk flow of parcels are delivered, in this system 900, the first robot 20 and the second robot 22 pick from separate areas in which discrete batches of parcels from the bulk flow of parcels are received.

Referring still to FIG. 18, in this exemplary embodiment, the first picking area 914a and the second picking area 914b are defined by a first trapdoor rejection mechanism 960a and a second trapdoor rejection mechanism 960b, respectively. Each trapdoor rejection mechanism 960a, 960b is configured to be selectively transitioned between a closed position and an open position. In use, each respective trapdoor rejection mechanism 960a, 960b is ordinarily in the closed position to temporarily support parcels directed to the trapdoor rejection mechanism prior to subsequent transfer by the first robot 20 or the second robot 22, but can selectively be transitioned to the open position to cause parcels identified as “unconveyable” to pass through the trapdoor rejection mechanism 960a, 960b. As such, each trapdoor rejection mechanism 960a, 960b is operably connected to the controller 40, such that each trapdoor rejection mechanism 960a, 960b can be selectively transitioned between the closed position and the open position in response to instructions (or signals) communicated from the controller 40. Suitable trapdoor rejection mechanisms which may be utilized within the system 900 include those described in U.S. patent application Ser. No. 17/748,479, which is incorporated herein by reference.

Referring still to FIG. 18, in this exemplary embodiment, parcels are delivered to the first robot 20 and the second robot 22 in a first direction, while the first place conveyor 916 and the second place conveyor 918 receive and transfer parcels away from the first robot 20 and the second robot 22 in a second direction, which is substantially perpendicular to the first direction.

Referring now to FIG. 19, this conveyor system 1000 (or system 1000) is substantially identical to that described above with reference to FIG. 18. The upstream conveyor 1012 in this system 1000 is also a chute which defines an inclined pathway along which a bulk flow of parcels can slide downward (under the force of gravity). Furthermore, the chute of the upstream conveyor 1012 is split into two sections 1012a, 1012b to divide the bulk flow of parcels into discrete batches, directing the batches to either a first picking area 1014a or a second picking area 1014b. In this exemplary embodiment, the first robot 20 is again configured to engage and transfer parcels from the first picking area 1014a to the first place conveyor 1016 (in response to instructions (signals) received from the controller 40), and the second robot 22 is configured to engage and transfer parcels from the second picking area 1014b to the second place conveyor 1018 (in response to instructions (signals) received from the controller 40). A buffering conveyor 1020 controls movement of the parcels from the first place conveyor 1016 to the second place conveyor 1018. In this regard, in at least some embodiments, the buffering conveyor 1020 would also be operably connected to and operate in response to instructions (signals) received from the controller 40 (FIG. 5).

Referring still to FIG. 19, in this exemplary embodiment, the first picking area 1014a and the second picking area 1014b are again defined by a first trapdoor rejection mechanism 1060a and a second trapdoor rejection mechanism 1060b, respectively. As in the exemplary system 900 described above with respect to FIG. 18, each trapdoor rejection mechanism 1060a, 1060b of the exemplary system 1000 is configured to be selectively transitioned between a closed position and an open position. In use, each respective trapdoor rejection mechanism 1060a, 1060b is ordinarily in the closed position to temporarily support parcels directed to the trapdoor rejection mechanism prior to subsequent transfer by the first robot 20 or the second robot 22, but can selectively be transitioned to the open position to cause parcels identified as “unconveyable” to pass through the trapdoor rejection mechanism 1060a, 1060b.

Referring still to FIG. 19, in this exemplary embodiment, there is an additional conveying module 1080 incorporated into the second place conveyor 1018, downstream of the location at which parcels are placed on the second place conveyor 1018 by the second robot 22. This additional conveying module 1080 is configured both to convey parcels along a longitudinal axis of the place conveyor 1018 and to selectively convey parcels in a transverse direction relative to the longitudinal axis, as indicated by arrow A in FIG. 19. For example, the module 1080 may be in the form of a belt with integrated rollers that effectuate the movement in the transverse direction. For another example, the module may be a divert and transfer module that is marketed and sold under the registered trademark MODSORT® by Regal Beloit America, Inc. Via use of this module 1080, parcels may be selectively moved out of the parcel flow on the second place conveyor 1018. In this regard, in at least some embodiments, the module 108 would also be operably connected to and operate in response to instructions (signals) received from the controller 40 (FIG. 5). For instance, if a parcel is successfully engaged and transferred by the first robot 20 or the second robot 22, but then is determined to be unconveyable for some reason (for example, is too heavy), the module 1080 can be activated to move the parcel in the transverse direction, where it can be discharged into a rejection chute (not shown) or otherwise delivered to another location for subsequent processing.

One of skill in the art will recognize that additional embodiments and implementations are also possible without departing from the teachings of the present invention. This detailed description, and particularly the specific details of the exemplary embodiments and implementations disclosed therein, is given primarily for clarity of understanding, and no unnecessary limitations are to be understood therefrom, for modifications will become obvious to those skilled in the art upon reading this disclosure and may be made without departing from the spirit or scope of the invention.

claim.claim-text: 1. A conveyor system, comprising:a first robot singulator;a second robot singulator;a picking area from which parcels of a bulk flow of parcels can be engaged and transferred by the first robot singulator or the second robot singulator;a first place conveyor positioned downstream of the picking area and configured to receive parcels transferred by the first robot singulator;a second place conveyor positioned downstream of the picking area and the first place conveyor, the second place conveyor configured to receive parcels transferred by the second robot singulator and further configured to receive parcels from the first place conveyor;a buffering conveyor positioned between the first place conveyor and the second place conveyor for regulating a rate at which parcels offloaded by the first place conveyor are transferred to the second place conveyor; anda vision and control subsystem operably connected to the first robot singulator, the second robot singulator, and the buffering conveyor, the vision and control subsystem includinga first camera for acquiring one or more images of the picking area and any parcels located in the picking area, anda controller including a processor for executing instructions stored in a memory component to (i) receive and process image data corresponding to an initial image of the picking area acquired by the first camera, (ii) selectively communicate instructions to the first robot singulator which cause the first robot singulator to engage and transfer parcels of the bulk flow of parcels positioned in the picking area to the first place conveyor, (iii) selectively communicate instructions to the second robot singulator which cause the second robot singulator to engage and transfer parcels positioned in the picking area to the second place conveyor, and (iv) selectively communicate instructions to the buffering conveyor which cause the buffering conveyor to index and transfer parcels from the first place conveyor to the second place conveyor.
2. The conveyor system according to claim 1, wherein the first robot singulator and the second robot singulator are each a six-axis robotic arm.

3. The conveyor system according to claim 1, wherein the picking area includes a first picking area and a second picking area, wherein the first robot singulator engages and transfers parcels positioned in the first picking area to the first place conveyor, and the second robot singulator engages and transfers parcels positioned in the second picking area to the second place conveyor.
4. The conveyor system according to claim 3, wherein the first picking area is aligned with the first place conveyor, and wherein the second picking area is aligned with the second place conveyor.
5. The conveyor system according to claim 3, wherein the first picking area is defined by a first section of a chute, and the second picking area is defined by a second section of the chute.

6. The conveyor system according to claim 1, wherein parcels are delivered to the first robot singulator and the second robot singulator in a first direction, and wherein the first place conveyor and the second place conveyor receive and transfer parcels away from the first robot singulator and the second robot singulator in a second direction, which is substantially perpendicular to the first direction.

7. The conveyor system according to claim 1, wherein the buffering conveyor comprises multiple buffering conveyors, with each of the multiple buffering conveyors being independently controlled by the vision and control subsystem to control movement of parcels from the first place conveyor to the second place conveyor.

8. The conveyor system according to claim 1, and further comprising an additional conveying module incorporated into the second place conveyor which is configured both to convey parcels along a longitudinal axis of the second place conveyor and to selectively convey parcels in a transverse direction relative to the longitudinal axis.

9. A conveyor system, comprising:a first robot singulator;a second robot singulator;a picking area, including a first picking area from which parcels of a bulk flow of parcels can be engaged and transferred by the first robot singulator, and a second picking area from which parcels of the bulk flow of parcels can be engaged and transferred by the second robot singulator;a first place conveyor positioned downstream of the picking area and configured to receive parcels transferred by the first robot singulator from the first picking area;a second place conveyor positioned downstream of the picking area and the first place conveyor, the second place conveyor configured to receive parcels transferred by the second robot singulator from the second picking area, and further configured to receive parcels from the first place conveyor; anda buffering conveyor positioned between the first place conveyor and the second place conveyor for regulating a rate at which parcels offloaded by the first place conveyor are transferred to the second place conveyor.

10. The conveyor system according to claim 9, and further comprising:a vision and control subsystem operably connected to the first robot singulator, the second robot singulator, and the buffering conveyor, the vision and control subsystem includinga first camera for acquiring one or more images of the picking area and any parcels located in the picking area, anda controller including a processor for executing instructions stored in a memory component to (i) receive and process image data corresponding to an initial image of the picking area acquired by the first camera, (ii) selectively communicate instructions to the first robot singulator which cause the first robot singulator to engage and transfer parcels of the bulk flow of parcels positioned in the first picking area to the first place conveyor, (iii) selectively communicate instructions to the second robot singulator which cause the second robot singulator to engage and transfer parcels positioned in the second picking area to the second place conveyor, and (iv) selectively communicate instructions to the buffering conveyor which cause the buffering conveyor to index and transfer parcels from the first place conveyor to the second place conveyor.
11. The conveyor system according to claim 9, wherein the first robot singulator and the second robot singulator are each a six-axis robotic arm.
12. The conveyor system according to claim 9, wherein the first picking area is aligned with the first place conveyor, and wherein the second picking area is aligned with the second place conveyor.
13. The conveyor system according to claim 9, wherein the first picking area is defined by a first section of a chute, and the second picking area is defined by a second section of the chute.

14. The conveyor system according to claim 9, wherein parcels are delivered to the first robot singulator and the second robot singulator in a first direction, and wherein the first place conveyor and the second place conveyor receive and transfer parcels away from the first robot singulator and the second robot singulator in a second direction, which is substantially perpendicular to the first direction.

15. The conveyor system according to claim 10, wherein the buffering conveyor comprises multiple buffering conveyors, with each of the multiple buffering conveyors being independently controlled by the vision and control subsystem to control movement of parcels from the first place conveyor to the second place conveyor.

16. The conveyor system according to claim 9, and further comprising an additional conveying module incorporated into the second place conveyor which is configured both to convey parcels along a longitudinal axis of the second place conveyor and to selectively convey parcels in a transverse direction relative to the longitudinal axis.
